description: From Middle English beten, from Old English bēatan (“to beat, pound, strike, lash, dash, thrust, hurt, injure”), from Proto-West Germanic *bautan, from Proto-Germanic *bautaną (“to push, strike”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰewd- (“to hit, strike”).
Compare Old Irish fo·botha (“he threatened”), Latin confutō (“I strike down”), fūstis (“stick, club”), Albanian bahe (“sling”), Lithuanian baudžiù, Old Armenian բութ (butʿ)).

entries.meaning: A stroke; a blow.
A pulsation or throb.
examples: a beat of the heart
the beat of the pulse

entries.meaning: (music) A pulse on the beat level, the metric level at which pulses are heard as the basic unit. Thus a beat is the basic time unit of a piece.
(music) The rhythm signalled by a conductor or other musician to the members of a group of musicians.
The instrumental portion of a piece of hip-hop music.
The interference between two tones of almost equal frequency
(authorship) A short pause in a play, screenplay, or teleplay, for dramatic or comedic effect.

definitionGroups.group: (by extension) An area of a person's responsibility, especially

entries.meaning: The route patrolled by a police officer or a guard.
examples: to walk the beat

entries.meaning: (journalism) The primary focus of a reporter's stories (such as police/courts, education, city government, business etc.).
examples: As an adult, I became a journalist whose beat is the environment. In a way, I’ve turned my youthful preoccupations into a profession.

entries.meaning: (dated) An act of reporting news or scientific results before a rival; a scoop.
examples: It's a beat on the whole country.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dated) That which beats, or surpasses, another or others.
examples: the beat of him

entries.meaning: (dated or obsolete, Southern US) A precinct.

definitionGroups.group: (dated) A place of habitual or frequent resort.

entries.meaning: (Australia) An area frequented by gay men in search of sexual activity. See gay beat.
(archaic) A low cheat or swindler.
examples: a dead beat

entries.meaning: (hunting) The act of scouring, or ranging over, a tract of land to rouse or drive out game; also, those so engaged, collectively.
examples: Bears coming out of holes in the rocks at the last moment, when the beat is close to them.

entries.meaning: (fencing) A smart tap on the adversary's blade.
(slang) A makeup look; compare beat one's face.

verbs.description: beat (third-person singular simple present beats, present participle beating, simple past beat, past participle beaten or (especially colloquial) beat)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hit; to strike.
examples: As soon as she heard that her father had died, she went into a rage and beat the wall with her fists until her knuckles bled.
Synonyms: knock, pound, strike, hammer, whack; see also Thesaurus:attack, Thesaurus:hit

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike or pound repeatedly, usually in some sort of rhythm.
examples: He danced hypnotically while she beat the atabaque.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To strike repeatedly; to inflict repeated blows; to knock vigorously or loudly.
(intransitive) To move with pulsation or throbbing.
(transitive) To win against; to defeat or overcome; to do or be better than (someone); to excel in a particular, competitive event.
examples: Jan had little trouble beating John in tennis. He lost five games in a row.
No matter how quickly Joe finished his test, Roger always beat him.
I just can't seem to beat the last level of this video game.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, nautical) To sail to windward using a series of alternate tacks across the wind.
(transitive) To strike (water, foliage etc.) in order to drive out game; to travel through (a forest etc.) for hunting.
To mix food in a rapid fashion. Compare whip.
examples: Beat the eggs and whip the cream.

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, in haggling for a price of a buyer) To persuade the seller to reduce a price.
examples: He wanted $50 for it, but I managed to beat him down to $35.
Synonym: negotiate

entries.meaning: (transitive) To indicate by beating or drumming.
examples: to beat a retreat; to beat to quarters

entries.meaning: To tread, as a path.
To exercise severely; to perplex; to trouble.
To be in agitation or doubt.
To make a sound when struck.
examples: The drums beat.

entries.meaning: (military, intransitive) To make a succession of strokes on a drum.
examples: The drummers beat to call soldiers to their quarters.

entries.meaning: To sound with more or less rapid alternations of greater and lesser intensity, so as to produce a pulsating effect; said of instruments, tones, or vibrations not perfectly in unison.
(transitive) To arrive at a place before someone.
examples: He beat me there.
The place is empty, we beat the crowd of people who come at lunch.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, MLE, MTE, slang, vulgar) To have sexual intercourse.
examples: Bruv, she came in just as we started to beat.
Synonyms: do it, get it on, have sex, shag; see also Thesaurus:copulate

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To rob.
examples: He beat me out of 12 bucks last night.

description: From Middle English bet (simple past of beten "to beat"), from Old English bēot (simple past of bēatan "to beat"). Middle English bet would regularly yield *beet; the modern form is influenced by the present stem and the past participle beaten. Pronunciations with /ɛ/ (from Middle English bette, alternative simple past of beten) are possibly analogous to read (/ɹɛd/), led, met, etc.

adjectives.description: beat (comparative more beat, superlative most beat)

entries.meaning: (US slang) Exhausted.
examples: After the long day, she was feeling completely beat.

entries.meaning: Dilapidated, beat up.
examples: Dude, you drive a beat car like that and you ain’t gonna get no honeys.

entries.meaning: (African-American Vernacular and gay slang) Having impressively attractive makeup.
examples: Her face was beat for the gods!

entries.meaning: (slang) Boring.
(slang, of a person) Ugly.
simple past tense of beat
(especially colloquial) past participle of beat

adjectives.description: beat (comparative more beat, superlative most beat)

entries.meaning: Relating to the Beat Generation.
examples: beat poetry

entries.meaning: A beatnik.
examples: The beats were pioneers with no destination, changing the world one impulse at a time.
